Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Long Term Human Adaptation in Beringia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Angela Gore, PhD candidate at Texas A&M University, will undertake research in central Alaska to understand the timing and settling-in processes of the First Americans and their descendants. Archeological and genomic evidence point to eastern Beringia as a gateway through which ancient peoples first migrated from Northeast Asia, therefore the rich archaeological record of central Alaska is key in unraveling questions of adaptation and behavior of the earliest Alaskans through time. The Alaskan record exhibits sizeable technological variability from 14 thousand to 5 thousand years ago and answers to questions about the first Alaskans are still elusive: how did ancient Beringians utilize and learn the landscape around them as they first encountered it? How did they adapt their technologies and mobile strategies through millennia of shifting climate and resulting resource fluctuation? This research expands knowledge of modern human adaptation and settlement of extreme northern environments and sheds light on the impact of climate change on human populations. This research provides a graduate student with a transformative research experience to be shared with academics, the public, and with Native Alaskans and First Nations peoples to whom it is directly relevant.

Gore will begin to unravel questions of landscape learning and behavioral variation in the archaeological record of central Alaska through the lens of stone tool procurement and use as evident in ancient toolkits. Mapping and sampling of the lithic sources within the Nenana River valley area, from outcrop to creek and river alluvium will reconstruct the lithic landscape exploited by prehistoric Alaskans. Geochemical analysis of non-obsidian volcanic stone sources in the valley provides a fingerprint of these sources against which artifacts from archaeological sites spanning 14 ka to 5 ka will be compared to reconstruct mobile strategies, landscape use, and changes in these behaviors through time. Gore will integrate geochemical toolstone sourcing with lithic analysis of these same archaeological collections to provide a comprehensive description of behavior and behavioral change of ancient Alaskans from colonization to settling-in on the landscape. Together, these methods provide a better understanding of the nuanced and complex interactions between landscape, environment and human culture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The archaeological record of interior Alaska is critical to understanding questions regarding human colonization and environmental adaptation of the First Americans and their descendants. The archaeological record of central Alaska is highly variable with no current consensus on any one explanation for this variability or how this record informs on behavioral processes such as environmental adaptation and landscape learning. One way to explore technological variability and human behavioral patterns is through studying lithic assemblages through the lens of raw material (toolstone) procurement and selection studies, aspects of lithic technological organization that reflect human behavioral decisions of the past preserved in the archaeological record.

We designed the research supported by this Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant to investigate and explain the variable late Pleistocene and Holocene record within one region, The Nenana River valley. We accomplished this by mapping the available toolstones in the valley and characterizing volcanic toolstones with portable X-Ray fluorescence (pXRF) geochemistry to compare with geochemical signatures of lithic assemblages spanning 13.5 ka to ~5.5 ka. Geochemical comparisons between known Nenana Valley volcanic rock sources (from both outcrops and waterways) and archaeological assemblages allows the reconstruction of mobile strategies and land-use, aspects of human behavior we are specifically interested in. Lithic technological analyses were conducted on these same assemblages to characterize patterns of toolstone selection and to assess how these patterns changed through time. Through integrating lithic technological analysis and geochemical sourcing, this project comprehensively describes how prehistoric Alaskans utilized the landscape around them as they colonized and settled-into the Nenana Valley, and the degree to which pronounced environmental shifts affected prehistoric adaptive behavioral strategies (e.g. land-use and technological repertoire).    

This research has provided new insights into the archaeological record of central Alaska. First, this project has resulted in the creation of a comprehensive map of the Nenana Valley lithic landscape, against which future studies involving raw material use and selection can be measured. This project successfully utilized pXRF geochemistry to replicate and expand upon previous studies in the region, adding to the number of geographically known sources of volcanic materials (e.g. basalt, dacite, rhyolite, and andesite) utilized by prehistoric occupants of the Nenana Valley, as well as identified new geochemical groups present in archaeological assemblages that do not have a known location within the valley. These contributions are significant in providing details about prehistoric behavioral strategies and provide direction for future studies. Interpretation of geochemical results coupled with lithic technological analysis of Nenana Valley assemblages currently indicates toolstone procurement and selection patterns are variable and changing through time, suggesting that humans responded behaviorally to a variety of environmental factors including changing climates and resultant shifts in animal and plant resources.

Funding for this project has resulted in several broader impacts. The completion of this project has provided more information about prehistoric humans living in eastern Beringia and is therefore directly relevant to Native Alaskans. Co-PI Gore has shared portions of this project with Native Alaskan community members through informal and academic presentations. We plan to continue the dissemination of results to both public and academic audiences to highlight the cultural and ecological history of Alaska, as well as the importance of ecological and environmental studies as they relate to past and current human behaviors. The completion of this project aided Co-PI Gore in obtaining data necessary for the completion of her Ph.D. dissertation research, providing her with a transformative and career-building research experience.
